qas.question: What do Samoans call their legislative body?
How many Fono members are there?
How many of the members of the Fono are elected to office?
What percentage of female matais are there in Samoa?
What position in government is chosen by Fono majority vote?
In what year was the Fono created?
What number of non-Samoans are in the country?
How many cabinet positions are appointed by women?

plausible_answers.text: no chiefly affiliation on separate electoral rolls

qas.question: What is one thing women don't have when they are members of the Fono?
In what year were women allowed to stand for election to the Samoan seats?

context: The unicameral legislature (<a0_0>the Fono<a0_0/>) consists of <a1_0>49<a1_0/> members serving 5-year terms. <a2_0>Forty-seven<a2_0/> are matai title-holders elected from territorial districts by Samoans; the other two are chosen by non-Samoans with <b8_0>no chiefly affiliation on separate electoral rolls<b8_0/>. Universal suffrage was adopted <b9_0>in <b5_0>1990<b9_0/><b5_0/>, but only chiefs (matai) may stand for election to the Samoan seats. There are <b6_0>more than 25,000<b6_0/> matais in the country, about <a3_0>5%<a3_0/> of whom are women. The <a4_0>prime minister<a4_0/>, chosen by a majority in the Fono, is appointed by the head of state to form a government. The prime minister's choices for the <b7_0>12<b7_0/> cabinet positions are appointed by the head of state, subject to the continuing confidence of the Fono.
